M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: (Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment – M.G.L. c. 186, § 14)

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as this action arises from a landlord-tenant relationship within the Court’s geographic jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as this action arises from a landlord-tenant relationship within the Court’s geographic jurisdiction.

Massachusetts General Laws chapter 186,.proposition: Under Massachusetts General Laws chapter 186, section 14, it is unlawful for a landlord, either directly or indirectly through neglect or omission, to interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of leased premises.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act meaningfully despite multiple complaints constitutes an **omission** proscribed by G.L. c. 186, § 14. See **Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714, 719 (1977) (landlord liable for breach of quiet enjoyment where disturbances by other tenants under landlord’s control interfered with tenant’s use); **Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (1982) (breach may arise from landlord’s failure to act to correct interference within their control); **A.J. Kimball Co. v. S. S. Kresge Co.**, 288 Mass. 422 (1934); **Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross**, 388 Mass. 16, 18 (1983); **Lowell Housing Auth. v. Melendez**, 449 Mass. 34, 41 (2007).

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 719.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act meaningfully despite multiple complaints constitutes an **omission** proscribed by G.L. c. 186, § 14. See **Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714, 719 (1977) (landlord liable for breach of quiet enjoyment where disturbances by other tenants under landlord’s control interfered with tenant’s use); **Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (1982) (breach may arise from landlord’s failure to act to correct interference within their control); **A.J. Kimball Co. v. S. S. Kresge Co.**, 288 Mass. 422 (1934); **Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross**, 388 Mass. 16, 18 (1983); **Lowell Housing Auth. v. Melendez**, 449 Mass. 34, 41 (2007).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 719.support_reasoning: Blackett does hold that a landlord can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment by failing to control disturbances caused by another tenant under the landlord’s control, and that nonfeasance/malfeasance distinctions should not shield the landlord. However, the case is not interpreting or applying G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it frame the landlord’s inaction as an ‘omission proscribed by § 14.’ It is instead a common‑law constructive eviction/quiet enjoyment decision, so citing it as statutory authority under § 14 overstates what the case holds, even though the general quiet‑enjoyment principle is consistent.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 719.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… To the extent that our opinions suggest a distinction between nonfeasance by the landlord… and malfeasance by the landlord, we decline to perpetuate that distinction where the landlord creates a situation and has the right to control the objectionable conditions.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (198.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act meaningfully despite multiple complaints constitutes an **omission** proscribed by G.L. c. 186, § 14. See **Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714, 719 (1977) (landlord liable for breach of quiet enjoyment where disturbances by other tenants under landlord’s control interfered with tenant’s use); **Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (1982) (breach may arise from landlord’s failure to act to correct interference within their control); **A.J. Kimball Co. v. S. S. Kresge Co.**, 288 Mass. 422 (1934); **Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross**, 388 Mass. 16, 18 (1983); **Lowell Housing Auth. v. Melendez**, 449 Mass. 34, 41 (2007).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly characterizes Gem’s liability as arising from its failure to act to prevent ongoing interference that was within its control. The court notes that Gem could have corrected the porous wall but did not, and then concludes that Gem violated its duty to Solomon “by outrageous omission to act” and is liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for permitting repeated flooding that interfered with quiet enjoyment. This directly supports the proposition that a landlord’s failure to act meaningfully in response to complaints can constitute an omission proscribed by § 14.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (198.relevant_excerpt: “There was evidence at trial that the wall between Solomon’s apartment and the adjoining basement area was extremely porous. There was also testimony suggesting that Gem may have considered cementing the wall to prevent floods, but never carried out this plan. The jury could reasonably conclude that Gem’s failure to do so caused Solomon’s injuries… In sum, it could be found that Gem violated its duty to Solomon recklessly, by outrageous omission to act, and thereby caused Solomon severe emotional harm… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it… permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

A.J. Kimball Co. v. S. S. Kresge Co., 28.raw_text: A.J. Kimball Co. v. S. S. Kresge Co., 288 Mass. 422 (1934)
A.J. Kimball Co. v. S. S. Kresge Co., 28.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act meaningfully despite multiple complaints constitutes an **omission** proscribed by G.L. c. 186, § 14. See **Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714, 719 (1977) (landlord liable for breach of quiet enjoyment where disturbances by other tenants under landlord’s control interfered with tenant’s use); **Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (1982) (breach may arise from landlord’s failure to act to correct interference within their control); **A.J. Kimball Co. v. S. S. Kresge Co.**, 288 Mass. 422 (1934); **Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross**, 388 Mass. 16, 18 (1983); **Lowell Housing Auth. v. Melendez**, 449 Mass. 34, 41 (2007).
A.J. Kimball Co. v. S. S. Kresge Co., 28.support_reasoning: The Kimball opinion is a securities/rescission case about alleged misrepresentations in the sale of stock and the plaintiff’s failure to tender the stock back; it does not involve landlord‑tenant relations, quiet enjoyment, G.L. c. 186, § 14, or any notion of liability for an omission in response to complaints. The court’s analysis is confined to misrepresentation, rescission requirements, and procedural aspects of an equity appeal, so it provides no authority for the proposition that a defendant’s failure to act meaningfully after complaints constitutes an actionable omission under § 14.
A.J. Kimball Co. v. S. S. Kresge Co., 28.relevant_excerpt: If it be assumed that a consideration of all the evidence warranted a finding of material misrepresentation of fact and that the plaintiff was induced to purchase the stock in reliance thereon in 1929, he could not rescind in August, 1931, because he has never made an actual tender of the certificates for said shares and the dividends received on account thereof.

Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.raw_text: Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross, 388 Mass. 16, 18 (1983)
Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act meaningfully despite multiple complaints constitutes an **omission** proscribed by G.L. c. 186, § 14. See **Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714, 719 (1977) (landlord liable for breach of quiet enjoyment where disturbances by other tenants under landlord’s control interfered with tenant’s use); **Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (1982) (breach may arise from landlord’s failure to act to correct interference within their control); **A.J. Kimball Co. v. S. S. Kresge Co.**, 288 Mass. 422 (1934); **Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross**, 388 Mass. 16, 18 (1983); **Lowell Housing Auth. v. Melendez**, 449 Mass. 34, 41 (2007).
Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.case_name: Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross
Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.support_reasoning: Coveney concerns a private college’s authority to discipline and expel a student and the validity of a release; it does not involve landlord-tenant law, quiet enjoyment, or G.L. c. 186, § 14. The opinion nowhere discusses a landlord’s omission or failure to act in response to complaints, nor any statutory duty under c. 186. Citing Coveney for the proposition that a landlord’s failure to act constitutes an omission proscribed by § 14 is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the case’s holding or reasoning.
Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.relevant_excerpt: “We dispose of this case on the ground that the college did not violate any contractual or other rights of the plaintiffs by expelling Coveney, and on the additional ground that Coveney waived the claims he asserts here by executing a valid and binding general release… A private university, college, or school may not arbitrarily or capriciously dismiss a student… If school officials act in good faith and on reasonable grounds, however, their decision to suspend or expel a student will not be subject to successful challenge in the courts.”

Lowell Housing Auth. v. Melendez, 449 Ma.raw_text: Lowell Housing Auth. v. Melendez, 449 Mass. 34, 41 (2007)
Lowell Housing Auth. v. Melendez, 449 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act meaningfully despite multiple complaints constitutes an **omission** proscribed by G.L. c. 186, § 14. See **Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714, 719 (1977) (landlord liable for breach of quiet enjoyment where disturbances by other tenants under landlord’s control interfered with tenant’s use); **Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (1982) (breach may arise from landlord’s failure to act to correct interference within their control); **A.J. Kimball Co. v. S. S. Kresge Co.**, 288 Mass. 422 (1934); **Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross**, 388 Mass. 16, 18 (1983); **Lowell Housing Auth. v. Melendez**, 449 Mass. 34, 41 (2007).
Lowell Housing Auth. v. Melendez, 449 Ma.support_reasoning: Melendez concerns whether off‑premises violent criminal activity by a tenant can justify termination of a public housing lease under statutory and lease language about threatening other tenants’ health, safety, or peaceful enjoyment. The court does not analyze omissions or a landlord’s failure to act in response to complaints; instead it addresses tenant misconduct and the housing authority’s discretion to evict. Therefore it does not support a proposition that a landlord’s failure to act meaningfully after complaints constitutes an omission proscribed by G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Lowell Housing Auth. v. Melendez, 449 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The lease provision in this case is in accordance with language contained in both the Federal and the State public housing statutes. Nothing in the lease, or in either statute, restricts the provision of ‘any criminal activity’ to activity that occurs on the premises. Not all criminal activity, however, is cause for termination. The limiting factor is that the criminal activity must ‘threaten[] the health, safety, or right to peaceful enjoyment’ of other tenants.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that continuous, unreasonable noise may constitute substantial interference amounting to breach of quiet enjoyment. See **Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); **Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway**, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); **Leardi v. Brown**, 394 Mass. 151 (1985); **Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); **Williams v. Seder**, 306 Mass. 134 (1940).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the Massachusetts statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment and clarifies that at least negligent conduct by the landlord is required for liability, but it does not address noise, continuous or otherwise. The case focuses on whether a statutory violation of the lead paint law, by itself, constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment and answers that question in the negative. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that continuous, unreasonable noise can be a substantial interference amounting to breach of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that continuous, unreasonable noise may constitute substantial interference amounting to breach of quiet enjoyment. See **Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); **Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway**, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); **Leardi v. Brown**, 394 Mass. 151 (1985); **Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); **Williams v. Seder**, 306 Mass. 134 (1940).
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: This excerpt from Hemingway (a concurrence/dissent) deals with implied warranty of habitability and statutory/code-based standards, not with G.L. c. 186, §14 or the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and it nowhere discusses noise, continuous noise, or interference with quiet enjoyment. The case is therefore not authority for the specific proposition that continuous, unreasonable noise can constitute substantial interference amounting to a breach of quiet enjoyment. The citation to Hemingway for that noise-based quiet enjoyment proposition is not supported by this text.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: I dissent from the statement of such a broad and sweeping new rule for the reason, in part, that it would be sufficient for the decision of these cases to hold that the landlord, in renting the apartments to the tenants, impliedly agreed that the apartments would comply with the several requirements of the Code which the tenants allege were violated, and that if the tenants sustain their burden of proof of such violations their liability for the unpaid rent may be reduced to the fair value of their use and occupancy of the apartments in their deficient condition.

Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151 (1985).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that continuous, unreasonable noise may constitute substantial interference amounting to breach of quiet enjoyment. See **Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); **Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway**, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); **Leardi v. Brown**, 394 Mass. 151 (1985); **Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); **Williams v. Seder**, 306 Mass. 134 (1940).
Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151 (1985).support_reasoning: Leardi concerns (1) whether the inclusion of illegal lease provisions constitutes an ‘injury’ under Chapter 93A, and (2) an individual tenant’s quiet-enjoyment claim based on threats over lease renewal. The court’s quiet-enjoyment discussion is limited to affirming that G.L. c. 186, § 14 requires ‘serious’ or ‘substantial’ interference and then finding on the facts that the landlord’s conduct did not meet that threshold. The opinion does not address noise at all, nor does it recognize continuous, unreasonable noise as a form of substantial interference, so it does not support the specific noise-based proposition.
Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151 (1985).relevant_excerpt: “Allisan claims that the judge erroneously concluded that G. L. c. 186, § 14, requires ‘substantial’ interference with her quiet enjoyment of the premises, and thus that he erroneously denied her claim under that statute. We disagree. ‘The phrase “quiet enjoyment” is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy ...’ (emphasis added). Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982). See Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (injury must be ‘substantial’ to afford ground for relief).”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that continuous, unreasonable noise may constitute substantial interference amounting to breach of quiet enjoyment. See **Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); **Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway**, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); **Leardi v. Brown**, 394 Mass. 151 (1985); **Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); **Williams v. Seder**, 306 Mass. 134 (1940).
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case discusses breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in the context of serious interference from drug-related criminal activity in common areas, but it does not address or recognize continuous, unreasonable noise as such interference. Noise is mentioned only incidentally as part of the plaintiffs’ description of drug activity, and the Court’s legal analysis and holding focus on the landlord’s failure to take measures to remove unlawful actors, not on noise as a standalone basis for breach. Thus, this opinion does not provide authority for the specific proposition that continuous unreasonable noise can constitute substantial interference breaching quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises…. If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Williams v. Seder, 306 Mass. 134 (1940).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that continuous, unreasonable noise may constitute substantial interference amounting to breach of quiet enjoyment. See **Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); **Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway**, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); **Leardi v. Brown**, 394 Mass. 151 (1985); **Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); **Williams v. Seder**, 306 Mass. 134 (1940).
Williams v. Seder, 306 Mass. 134 (1940).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns rent increases in a tenancy at will and the effect of unilateral notices of increased rent. It does not discuss quiet enjoyment, nuisance, or noise, nor does it address whether continuous, unreasonable noise can be a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment. Citing Williams v. Seder for that specific quiet-enjoyment/noise proposition is therefore inaccurate.
Williams v. Seder, 306 Mass. 134 (1940).relevant_excerpt: A tenancy at will arises out of an agreement, express or implied, by which one uses and occupies the premises of another for a consideration — usually the payment of rent. The relation between the tenant and the landlord is contractual. … The notices purporting to increase the rent were not notices to quit, and the plaintiff never expressed any intent to have the tenant vacate her premises. … The terms of the existing tenancy could not be changed and a new tenancy at will be substituted for the former tenancy unless with the mutual assent of the parties.
